text: Para, this for, para, can also mean in order to, in order to.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So in a sentence, for example, we have spoken in order to resolve it.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We have spoken in order to resolve it.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now in English, we could just say we have spoken to resolve it.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: No, we don't need to say in order to, but whenever we have this to meaning in order to, we want to translate this as para in Spanish.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: First bit is we have spoken.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: To resolve it, in order to resolve it.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So we have spoken in order to resolve it.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So whilst the to of to resolve, resolver, would fit nicely here.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: I mean, if we were to translate directly from English, we have spoken to resolve it.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Whenever this to means in order to, we must put that para.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You could say we have spoken in order to try to resolve it.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What was to try related to intention?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We have spoken in order to try to resolve it.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So only when the to implies in order to, we want to put para.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The to form of verb in Spanish is not enough to include that meaning.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So for example, if you want to say I'm here to see you, does it mean I'm here in order to see you?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So I am here to see you informally.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: This is also something we could learn or interiorize through the negative language transfer that some Spanish speakers make when they speak English.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: For example, you might hear a Spanish speaker say, I am here for see you or for seeing you.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You might hear a Spanish speaker, especially with basic English, making this mistake.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, once you heard that a few times, you would say, oh, maybe this is how you say it in Spanish.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So we don't want to forget this opportunity, the opportunity to learn from the negative language transfer, the mistakes that Spanish speakers make in English, which originate from Spanish.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Once you hear the same mistake a few times, you can assume it probably comes from Spanish.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: I have called you in order to speak about it.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So the first bit is I have called you.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: In order to speak about it.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So if we take the sentence in English, I have called you to speak about it and we translate it then we will say, but when a to means in order to, we must put this para.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: I have called you in order to speak about it.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What was to be for states?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And we said that we can use this to express when we are doing something right now.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: I am eating using this structure with estar and then the ing form of the verb.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Do you remember how you would get the ing form of comer, for example, of er or ir verbs?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So we add on yendo for er, ir verbs and for our verbs we add on and on.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how would you say I am eating?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: To explain, we would go from explanation, but explanation is an exception.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: It's not explanación in Spanish as we might hope.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: It's explicación and we see we even have that k sound in explain, explicación.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We have it in English as well in inexplicable.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: For example, we say in English inexplicable in Spanish.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So we can see where that sound's coming from.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how is explanation or explication in Spanish?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So I'm explaining it and you mean right now.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The lo can go on the end of a to form, but they can also go on the end of one of these ando or yendo forms as well.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Actually in explicar, we get this plicar from plicare that we mentioned before, meaning to fold in Latin.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So explicar, to explain, to unfold.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You might want to say I'm taking a Spanish course.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Even if you're not in the course right now in this moment, when we are taking a course in our minds, there's a period of time in which we are taking a course.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And when we say it, we're in that period of time.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: If I say I'm taking a Spanish course, maybe I mean for three months and I'm in that period.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Do you remember what to take was?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We used it with to take a photo.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: I'm going to let you guess it.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: It's not with a, it's with o.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: This is how you would say a Spanish course, a course of Spanish.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, what if we put this estoy in the past tense that we learned?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The past tense that is aba or ia.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: I was taking a Spanish course.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Which means we actually have two ways of saying I was taking.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We can say estaba tomando or we can just use tomar and use that line in the past.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So both tomaba and estaba tomando mean I was taking.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say I was eating?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Or how else could you say it?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So you have this option comía or estaba comiendo.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Most of the time they're interchangeable.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Sometimes one might fit slightly better than the other and it's something you will pick up very naturally when you're practicing.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So if in one situation people tend to use estaba comiendo rather than comía, you will pick it up.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So we have ando and yendo to form this ing and we saw in Spanish that we don't use it after prepositions.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You don't use this ing either if you say something like swimming is healthy or running is healthy.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You don't use the ing there either.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You would just say to run is healthy.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: If you hear people toast in Spanish, you might hear them say salud, which means health.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So we're seeing that we don't use the ing in Spanish as much as we do in English.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Sometimes in English we make an adjective with ing.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We go from to interest to interesting.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: When we do this in English, this ing that we use in English to form an adjective in Spanish, it's ande for are verbs and yende for are verbs.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So for example, we had to interest.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So if you get rid of are and you put ante, you get that ing adjective interesting.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how would you say interesting?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So when you make an adjective with ing in English from the verb, you can just replace it with ante or yente.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say to irritate in Spanish?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And you can go from irritation.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So if you want to say irritating.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say to frustrate in Spanish?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Yes, because you have the two R's now.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: When the moon gets smaller, it's waning.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And the moon is la luna.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how would you say the waning moon?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So there we're making waning like an adjective, not like the verb.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: I don't know if you ever noticed like in English, Monday is moon day.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: It's not very obvious in English that the days of the week relate back to the planets.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But in Spanish, it's very obvious.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You have la luna, the moon, and then you have lunes, monday.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What planet does that sound like?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Jueves in Spanish is spelled with a J.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So you can see much clearer there how our days of the week are named after planets.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We have a star for states and for characteristics.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And we said that un ser.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Un ser means a being that we can use ser like a noun and we get a being.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So a human being is un ser humano.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You could also say a living being.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You could say un ser vivo.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Vivo is also like an adjective which means alive.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But living is adjective that we make with ing.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We can build it from vivir.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: For r verbs we have ante and for ir verbs we have yente.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What does to go out or to leave?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: To go out or to leave.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: I don't care if it's wrong, but I want it to end in a.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now we have in English you might have heard salient which means kind of protruding or outstanding or something that stands out or sticks out or protrudes.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: This is Latin English version of this ante yente rule.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So we can see it even in English.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would salient be in Spanish?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You can go from salient or you can go from salir.
